citation.article-title: Isolation and characterization of a strictly anaerobic, cellulolytic spore former: Clostridium chartatabidum sp. nov.

p.s: Description of Clostridium chartatabidum sp. nov.
Clostridium chartatabidum (char'ta'tab'id'um; L. noun, charta, paper; L. adj., tabidus, dissolving; M. L. adj., chartatabidum, paper-dissolving)
Cells are readily decolourised Gram-positive rods, 1 μ by 3-6 μ, peritrichously flagellated.
They form rod-shaped spores 0.7 μ by 2-3.5 μ long which are located centrally to subterminally.
Colonies form orange centres, with colourless edges and are umbonate with a lobate to undulate edge.
Ferments cellulose, cellobiose, sucrose, fructose, glucose salicin, xylose.
Hydrogen, acetate, butyrate and ethanol are fermentation products.
Rumen fluid is required for optimum growth.
